prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Factors militating against transfer—Advancement of cases toward trial

para.paratext: The Panel may consider the fact that cases potentially to be transferred are advancing toward trial.[1] If discovery is completed and a trial scheduled in an action, it is quite unlikely that transfer would be ordered.[2] The scheduling of a final pretrial conference in one of the actions to be transferred has also prevented transfer.[3] This factor reflects the diminishing value coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings would have on cases as they become ready for trial and pretrial proceedings are completed. Cases need not be set nor nearing trial; it may be enough that they have been pending in the districts in which they were filed for long enough that the Panel views centralization as offering diminished benefits and the likelihood of greater disruption of the litigation process.[4] In one case, the Panel noted that were cases had been pending for four years, the remaining common issues did not support transfer.[5] The fact the cases are advancing toward trial may be noted by the Panel.[6]

In one case involving only two actions, the Panel declined to order transfer, in part, on the basis of the progress one of the cases was making toward trial.[7] The Panel noted that this factor is especially likely to be important in multidistrict litigation involving few cases:

When only a small number of actions are being considered for transfer under Section 1407, the imminency of trial of one of those actions, as is the case here, is an additional factor weighing against the institution of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[8]

This factor would be considered in litigation involving more cases and would also support separation and remand of the single case on the verge of trial.[9] Even where there are numerous actions, if they are approaching the conclusion of pretrial proceedings or are otherwise procedurally advanced, the Panel is likely to deny centralization.[10] Similarly, if a global settlement appears to be at hand, the Panel is unlikely to disrupt the cases by ordering any transfers.[11] In addition to the overall advancement towards trial, the Panel is likely to view great disparity in how cases are progressing toward trial as a factor militating against transfer.[12]

The Panel's aversion to centralizing cases that are nearing the completion of pretrial proceedings is fundamental and inherent of the purposes of centralization. Since centralization will last only until the completion of pretrial proceedings in the transferred cases, there is constantly diminishing value to centralization as the cases proceed toward trial.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
